text: If there’s one man in Hollywood that knows
the value of chemistry, it’s Michael Bay.
He’s taught society that in the face of
a half-baked story and thin script,
big budget explosions can
save face at the box office.
That’s right folks, today we’re talking
pyrotechnics – Hollywood’s go-to
distraction from a bad plot.
(Reactions Splash)
Pyrotechnics involve reactions
that turn potential energy
(in the form of chemical bonds) into heat,
hot expanding gases and kinetic energy.
Explosions are a type of thermal
decomposition reaction designed to produce
high temperatures and huge volumes of gas.
The volume of gas produced is much larger
than the solids in the explosive materials.
The reaction, which happens quickly,
creates a buildup of pressure that
releases in the form of an explosive shockwave.
Dynamite is designed to pack
a mighty punch by creating high
pressures at detonation.
This “punch” is known as “brisance” or shattering power.
Although there has not been any peer
reviewed literature on the subject,
it’s our theory that there is a positive
correlation between the brisance of an
onscreen explosion and the amount of money
Michael Bay receives from his films.
Many explosives are created by combining ingredients.
Dynamite is a combination of TNT
(trinitrotoluene) and nitroglycerin.
Another example is modern gunpowder
which contains nitroglycerin and
nitrocellulose along with other compounds.
The gunpowder used in modern ammunition
burns very fast, but it does
not detonate like TNT.
What these two have in common is creation
of lots and lots of hot expanding gas.
When mixtures are created to do this,
two key ingredients are needed – fuel and oxidizers.
The first gunpowder, invented thousands
of years ago, combined carbon
(charcoal), sulfur, and saltpeter.
Saltpeter is potassium nitrate or
KNO3 which is the oxidizer while the
carbon and sulfur act as the fuel.
This mixture is no longer used in modern
ammunition as it produces copious smoke
but in Hollywood this is no problem.
In fact, it can be an advantage used
to create dramatic effects by Pyrotechnicians.
Mixtures such as gunpowder are
Class B explosives because they
will burn but won’t necessarily
explode unless they’re confined.
Let me give you an example.
When a gun is fired, the propellant
(which is the gunpowder) burns
incredibly fast, but it does not
explode because of the way is
it packed in the ammunition.
You still hear a loud noise when
the pressure sends the bullet flying out,
but if you set off that same amount
of gunpowder outside of a gun,
it would burn fairly quietly.
This is due to the fact because it
is outside of the gun barrel and
the hot gas can dissipate quickly.
This property offers Pyrotechnicians
a little more control over their explosions
because you know the drill people:
safety first!
So with your new knowledge of
Hollywood magic, go binge watch
some Michael Bay masterpieces
and learn something.
But before you do so, here’s two
more awesome chemistry videos
you should probably check out.
Also, you probably want to subscribe.
All you have to do is click that button.
It’s that easy.
Alright folks we will see you again soon.
